cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Astral Above Elemental Below
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Astral Plane
planes.philosophicalEssence: A realm of thought and dream, where visitors travel as disembodied souls to reach the Outer Planes.
planes.emotionalInfluence: None specified; the plane is a vast silvery sea of thought, memory, and dream.

physicalProperties.shape: A great silvery sea, the same above and below, with swirling wisps of white and gray streaking among motes of light—the distant stars of far-flung Wildspace systems.
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst.

temperature.description: No specific temperature hazards mentioned for the Astral Plane.

physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: Psychic winds are storms of thought that batter travelers' minds rather than their bodies.

timeFlow.description: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst. For this reason, creatures that live on the Astral Plane (such as githyanki) establish outposts on other planes, often the Material Plane, so their children can grow to maturity.

hazards.name: Psychic Wind
hazards.description: A psychic wind is a storm of thought that batters travelers' minds rather than their bodies. The storm is made of lost memories, forgotten ideas, and subconscious fears that went astray in the Astral Plane and conglomerated into this powerful force. A psychic wind is first sensed as a rapid darkening of the silver-gray sky. After 1d4 minutes, the area becomes as dark as a moonless night. As the sky darkens, the traveler feels buffeting and shaking. As quickly as it comes, the psychic wind passes, and the sky returns to normal in 1 minute.

savingThrowToTraverse.triggerDescription: Each traveler caught in a psychic wind makes a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the traveler suffers a random psychic effect.

onFailure.description: On a failed save, the traveler suffers a random effect from the Psychic Wind Psychic Effects table: Stunned for 1 minute (d20 1-8), 2d10 Psychic damage (d20 9-12), 4d10 Psychic damage (d20 13-17), or Unconscious for 1d10 hours (d20 18-20).

onSuccess.description: The traveler avoids the psychic effects of the wind but is still subject to the location effect.

savingThrowToTraverse.repeatSaveTiming: End of each turn (for Stunned effect only)
recoveryMethods: Taking damage or another creature shaking you awake (for Unconscious effect)

detectionMethod.warningDescription: A psychic wind is first sensed as a rapid darkening of the silver-gray sky. After 1d4 minutes, the area becomes as dark as a moonless night.

entries.description: At the end of the travel time, the characters arrive at a location other than the intended destination.

entries.effect: Sent through a random color pool
entries.description: Roll on the Astral Color Pools table to determine destination.

entries.effect: Stunned for 1 minute; repeat the saving throw at the end of each of your turns, ending the effect on yourself on a success.
entries.durationDescription: 1 minute, repeat save at end of each turn

entries.effect: Unconscious for 5 (1d10) hours; the effect ends if you take damage or if another creature takes an action to shake you awake.

environmentalEffects.name: Agelessness
environmentalEffects.description: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Creatures on the Astral Plane do not age. They do not need food or water. For this reason, creatures that live on the Astral Plane (such as githyanki) establish outposts on other planes so their children can grow to maturity.

environmentalEffects.name: Thought-Based Movement
environmentalEffects.description: A traveler in the Astral Plane can move by simply thinking about moving, but distance has little meaning. In combat, a creature has a Fly Speed (in feet) equal to 5 times its Intelligence score and can hover.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: In combat, a creature's Fly Speed in feet equals 5 × its Intelligence score, and the creature can hover. Outside combat, movement is accomplished by the power of thought, and distance has little meaning.

gravityModel.description: The Astral Plane has no gravity. Movement is accomplished by the power of thought. In combat, a creature has a Fly Speed equal to 5 times its Intelligence score and can hover.

travelTimeModel.formula: 4d6 days to a specific location, or 1d4 × 10 hours to a general location such as a color pool leading to a specified plane

environmentalEffects.name: Thought-Based Navigation
environmentalEffects.description: All that is required to find one's destination is to think about it. As long as the destination is somewhere in the Astral Plane or in Wildspace, thinking about a place makes the creature aware of the most direct route to that location. The creature doesn't know how long the journey will take or how perilous it will be, just which direction to go in.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Thinking about a destination on the Astral Plane or in Wildspace reveals the most direct route. Travel time to a specific location (e.g. a particular Wildspace system or Astral outpost) takes 4d6 days. Travel to a general location (e.g. a color pool leading to a specified plane) takes 1d4 × 10 hours.

portals.name: Color Pool
portals.destinationPlane: Various (determined by d20 roll on Astral Color Pools table)
portals.colorOrAppearance: Two-dimensional pools of rippling colors, perceived by the Astral self rather than by physical eyes. Colors are understood rather than seen.

planarConnections.name: Wildspace Systems
planarConnections.description: Vast, airless expanses called Wildspace systems bob in the Astral Plane like corks in an ocean. In these systems, the Astral Plane overlaps with the Material Plane, and the stars and planets of the Material Plane are accessible from the Astral Plane. Every world of the Material Plane is situated in a Wildspace system. Creatures and objects in Wildspace age normally and exist on both the Astral Plane and Material Plane simultaneously.

planarConnections.name: Yggdrasil (World Tree) Branches
planarConnections.description: Yggdrasil's branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane. Its roots reach into the Lower Planes. Planar travelers can climb among the roots and branches to travel from plane to plane or world to world.

planarConnections.name: Portals from the Plain of Infinite Portals
planarConnections.description: The Plain of Infinite Portals (Layer 1 of the Abyss) contains portals to the Astral Plane, making this layer the best way to escape the horrors of the Abyss.

notableEntities.name: Githyanki
notableEntities.description: Githyanki live on the Astral Plane. Because creatures on the Astral Plane don't age, githyanki establish outposts on other planes (often the Material Plane) so their children can grow to maturity.

notableEntities.name: Tu'narath
notableEntities.description: The githyanki city of Tu'narath is perhaps the most infamous city built on the petrified corpse of a dead god. It is hollowed out beneath the surface of the dead god's remains.

civilizations.name: Githyanki
civilizations.description: Githyanki establish outposts on the Astral Plane, often building cities on the petrified corpses of dead gods. Tu'narath is the most infamous such city.
civilizations.location: Various locations on the Astral Plane, notably on petrified dead god corpses

specialRules.name: No Aging
specialRules.description: Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age or suffer from hunger or thirst.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Aging is suspended. Hunger and thirst do not apply. Creatures that live on the Astral Plane establish outposts on other planes so their children can grow to maturity.

specialRules.name: Thought-Based Movement
specialRules.description: A traveler in the Astral Plane can move by simply thinking about moving. In combat, a creature has a Fly Speed (in feet) equal to 5 times its Intelligence score and can hover.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Fly Speed = 5 × Intelligence score (in feet). The creature can hover. Outside combat, distance has little meaning and movement is accomplished by thought.

specialRules.name: Thought-Based Navigation
specialRules.description: Thinking about a destination on the Astral Plane or in Wildspace makes the creature aware of the most direct route to that location. The creature doesn't know how long the journey will take or how perilous it will be.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Travel to a specific location takes 4d6 days. Travel to a general location (such as a color pool leading to a specified plane) takes 1d4 × 10 hours. DM decides travel time.

specialRules.name: Dead Gods
specialRules.description: The Astral Plane is where the petrified remains of dead gods end up—gods who were slain by more powerful entities or who lost all their mortal worshipers and perished as a result. A dead god looks like a gigantic, nondescript stone statue that bears little resemblance to the divine entity it once was.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Dead gods appear as gigantic nondescript stone statues. Githyanki, mind flayers, and other residents sometimes turn these drifting hulks into outposts and cities, many of which are hollowed out beneath the surface.

specialRules.name: Wildspace Overlap
specialRules.description: Wildspace systems are vast, airless expanses where the Astral Plane overlaps with the Material Plane. Creatures and objects in Wildspace age normally and exist on both planes simultaneously. This enables use of spells like Teleport to travel between Wildspace and a nearby world.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: In Wildspace, creatures age normally (unlike the rest of the Astral Plane). Creatures exist on both the Astral and Material Planes simultaneously. Spells such as Teleport can be used to travel from Wildspace to a nearby world or vice versa.

modifiedSpells.modification: Can be used to travel from Wildspace to a nearby world or vice versa, due to the overlap of the Astral and Material Planes in Wildspace.

adventureThemes: Traveling to Outer Planes via color pools
Traveling to different Material Plane worlds via Wildspace
Encountering fellow travelers (Celestials, Fiends, slaadi, modrons, githyanki)
Plumbing crystallized thoughts of dead gods
Sifting information from the torrent of a psychic wind
Facing Astral manifestations of own memories, fears, and dreams

crossReferences.description: Contains extensive information about Wildspace and Astral travel.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Infinite Staircase
globalPlanarConnections.description: An extradimensional staircase that connects the planes. An entrance usually appears as a nondescript door. Beyond the portal lies a small landing with a stairway leading up and down. The staircase changes appearance as it climbs and descends. It includes ramps, hovering platforms, and clockwork conveyor belts along its endless construction.
navigableBy: Any creature that can find a door

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Oceanus
globalPlanarConnections.description: The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, with headwaters in the Blessed Fields of Elysium. It flows through each of Elysium's layers, passes through the top layer of the Beastlands, streams across the top layer of Arborea, and finally drains away somewhere in Arborea's second layer.

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Styx
globalPlanarConnections.description: The River Styx bubbles with grease, foul flotsam, and the putrid remains of battles along its banks. It churns through the top layers of Acheron, the Nine Hells, Gehenna, Hades, Carceri, the Abyss, and Pandemonium. Tributaries snake through lower layers of these planes.
hazards: Ill effects of the Styx (see chapter 3)
navigableBy: Sinister ferries crewed by skilled pilots

globalPlanarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
globalPlanarConnections.description: A cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes. Most of its massive trunk rises through Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane.

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals
planarTravelMethods.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some function like doorways; others are locations that exist on multiple planes at once or flicker between planes. Some are vortices joining an Elemental Plane with a similar Material Plane location.
requirements: Meeting portal requirements (command, key item, random, situation, or time-based)
risks: Requirements may be difficult to discover
destinations: Any plane, depending on the specific portal

planarTravelMethods.name: Gate spell
planarTravelMethods.description: Gate can directly transport adventurers to any other plane of existence.

planarTravelMethods.name: Plane Shift spell
planarTravelMethods.description: Plane Shift can directly transport adventurers to any other plane, with different degrees of precision compared to Gate.
requirements: Tuning fork attuned to destination plane

planarTravelMethods.name: Etherealness spell
planarTravelMethods.description: Etherealness allows adventurers to enter the Ethereal Plane.

planarTravelMethods.name: Astral Projection spell
planarTravelMethods.description: Astral Projection lets adventurers project themselves into the Astral Plane and from there travel to the Outer Planes.

infernalHierarchy.title: Duke/Duchess
canDemoteTo: Any lesser or greater devil form

infernalHierarchy.title: Archduke/Archduchess
canDemoteTo: Any lesser or greater devil form

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to a Celestial's or Fiend's nature.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each failed save adds another 1d4 subtracted from all D20 Tests.

onSuccess.description: The creature resists the dissonance for this rest period.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
